text: Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill. Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: So that’s one. Normally it takes three to sometimes four doses… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …for it to work and that’s true for most medicines. It takes three to four doses of anything for anything to work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t have enough in your blood stream to do anything.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And there always is the possibility that when you go through some of this checking, you’re not eligible. Patient: Um. Doctor: Okay, I think we have ninety days from when you got your first shot, which was November six or seven – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway.

text: Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t. Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
